title: Difference between convergence and divergence? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think if a sequence and series approaches a definite value such series and sequence are called convergent otherwise divergent. For example: a sequence is given as 1,1/2,1/3,1/4,….. up to infinity so by seeing this you can say that its going on decreasing such as… 1,0.5,0.3,…. and you will be cent % sure that it will never became negative. and if this sequence approaches to infinity then this the reusult of this sequence must be approach at zero.Hence it is a definite number so we call that above sequence is convergent.similarly, 1,2,3,4…… it will not approaches at any fixed number so it is divergent.

Converges comes together, Diverges grows apart. In math the sum of a geometric series will converge, approach a limit, if the common ratio less than 1. As an example: 100 + 50 +25 + 12.5 + 6.25 + … Converges to 200. The formula for the point at which it converges to is: Sn=t1 X (1-r^n)/(1-r). Where n is the sum of all terms, t1 is the first term, r is the common ratio, and n is the number of terms. But if the common ratio is greater than 1 then the series will diverge, not approach a limit. As an example: 1 + 1.5 + 2.25 + 3.75 + 5.065 + … is not bounded by any limit so the sum of this series diverges.
